B00003CXBH|5.0|I thoroughly enjoyed watching The Mission.  The acting, cinematography and film score were outstanding, and the message was profound. <BR>     A group of Spanish Jesuit missionaries christianize a tribe of Guarani indians living along the border between Paraguay and Brazil.  They set up a mission, San Marcos, and achieve impressive results related to the protection, organization, education and christianization of the Guarani.  The story of their success is told with love and in a way that clearly demonstrates the magnitude of the work that was accomplished, especially in face of the opposition that the priests faced from their Spanish compatriots who wanted to exploit the natural and human resources of the Guarani land.  <BR>     Suddenly Portugal, which was awarded the Guarani land under the treaty of Madrid, demands that San Carlos be closed and the priests withdrawn under threat of military invasion. The film follows the desperate efforts of the priests of San Marcos to  protect the indian land from Portugese invasion and save the mission through diplomatic, pacific and even military action. <BR>     This marvelous story reflects the brutality of a world order of empires dedicated to the pitiless exploitation of the natural and human resources of their colonies.  In the end it all comes down to San Marcos, can it be allowed stand as a beacon of christian love and understanding among the indians or must it be sacrificed to the political realities of empire?
B0000508U6|5.0|In the past decade of so, a transition or sorts has begun in British rock music.  While<BR>many British bands still dwell upon their \\"Beatle-Esque\\" sounds, a new wave of musicians have<BR>begun striking out with their own amazing sounds.  Perhaps the finest of these new wave bands<BR>is Coldplay.<BR> Through haunting lyrics and an imaginative sound, Coldplay's Parachutes is a prime<BR>example of a new wave of Britain rock.  One of the more powerful songs on Parachutes is<BR>Shiver.  Alternately intense and relaxed, Shiver is a classic rock song with a new twist.  Guitarist<BR>Jon Buckland transfers between an amazing rock riff on the chorus, and a subtle guitar line on<BR>the verse, while lead singer Chris Martin cooly sings &quot;you'll always get your way&quot; to a woman<BR>who ignores him, pledging &quot;I'll be there by your side, just you try and stop me.&quot;  This amazing<BR>mix of vocals and melody makes Shiver perhaps the best song on the entire album.  <BR> Yet another love song, Yellow, the first major hit off Parachutes, tells of Martin's<BR>apparent love of a woman stating, \\"Look at the stars, look how they shine for you, and<BR>everything you do.\\"  Martin then goes on to state all of the things he would do for the object of<BR>his affection in a modern day love ballad.  Another popular single, Trouble, exhibits Martins<BR>amazing piano skills.  In it, Martin apologizes for &quot;all the stupid things I've done&quot; swearing, &quot;I<BR>never meant to do you wrong.&quot; The lyrics mixed with Martin's voice and piano playing are both<BR>appealing and modest in meaning, while at the same time apologetic and sincere.  <BR> The CD's short title track, containing only Martin's voice accompanied with an acoustic<BR>guitar, is one of the many songs on Parachutes in which Martin pledges his love and tells how he<BR>will patiently wait for the object of his affection.  Although short in length, it is a song of deep<BR>human emotions.  Yet another song containing a pledge of love is Sparks.  Unlike most of the<BR>other songs on Parachutes, Sparks lets guitarist Jon Buckley really show his talent through<BR>melodic guitar rifts.  Martin's lyrics once again are cool and moody as they convey his emotions<BR>through the songs tone.    <BR> Although almost every song on Parachutes is very listenable there are a few dark spots to<BR>keep the CD from perfection.  An example would be the track titled Spies.  Even though the<BR>song contains a good melodic sound, at times the lyrics are a bit silly, imagining a world filled<br />with spies and then seeing &quot;that no one is free, we're all fugitives.&quot;  The song also drags on a bit<BR>too long making it seem repetitive.  Another fault is the first track on the CD don't panic. <BR>Although the songs message is one of hope and persevearance, it lacks the upbeat rythym of the<BR>other tracks.  It is also the only track in which Martin's vocals fail to blend with the melody of<BR>the rest of the band.     <BR> The song Everything's Not Lost has the melancholy piano of a old love ballad as Martin<BR>attempts to stay optimistic through his lyrics even as he's &quot;counting up my demons&quot;  The song<BR>finishes with a slow fade out of &quot;oh yeah, everything's not lost&quot; in a sort of tribute to the Beatles<BR>Hey Jude. Everything's Not Lost is followed by Parachutes' hidden track, Life Is For Living, yet <BR>another Martin apology. It's a rather nice finish to a good CD with a melancholy but rich sound,<BR>filled out by an orchestral accompanyment. <BR> Parachutes is a very appealing record. Although it's not always that exciting to listen to,<BR>it consistantly emits a nice, dreamlike atmosphere which at times is very nice to listen to. Lead<BR>singer Chris Martin may not be the most remarkable singer in the world, but in his vocals and<BR>lyrics, he presents an appealingly real and likable personality that allows listeners to really enjoy<BR>listening to his music.

You'd think that it would be a much better song, with Madonna on the track, and since Britney obviously now has something to prove to everyone. Almost every song sounds like it could be a hip hop song. <br />Songs like \\"Outrageous\\" and \\"Toxic\\" really take the cake and are most likely two of the tracks you'll want to play over and over again! And I just have to mention \\"Showdown\\" and \\"The Hookup\\" just because of their unique and catchy sound. <br />Aside from \\"Outrageous\\" and \\"Toxic,\\" though, the one song on this cd that totally grabbed my attention was \\"Everytime.\\" It's a little Janet Jackson-ish, but the piano is very nice and emotional, totalling befitting of what she's singing about. This is probably one of the stronger songs on the cd, lyrically and generally. It's obviously about her and Justin Timberlake, and I really have to applaud her for A) recording her most emotional song yet and B) singing such a nice and apologetic song about Justin after he totally ripped her to shreds in his song/video, \\"Cry Me A River.\\" <br />So even if you don't like \\"Me Against the Music,\\" are just plain ready to give up on Britney or totally enjoyed her last cd, definitely give this cd a listen. It's worth it!

B0000DJZA5|5.0|This is the album they should have released after the incredible white album. Both Glyn Johns &quot;Get Back&quot; albums were and are still awful, sounding like a bunch of demos by an average band, and the Beatles were never an average band. Those albums were never released because all 4 Beatles rejected them back in 1969 and 1970, so why should they release them now? After rejecting the Johns versions, John &amp; George gave the tapes to Phil Spector and let him do whatever he liked with them, typical of Lennon and Harrison 1970s behaviour towards the group (&quot;the dream is over&quot;, &quot;I dont believe in Beatles&quot; and that kind of stuff). Spector, being Spector, destroyed the original sound and concept. So here we are, for the first time we have the &quot;should-have-been&quot; Let It Be. We can now at last throw away the &quot;reproduced for disc by Phil Spector&quot; CD, replace it with Naked, reprogram our CD player and play it straight after the White Album, like it should have been back in 1969. <BR>This is an incredibly sounding, excellent CD. Go and buy it NOW. You wont be dissapointed.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|Check out 'Let It Be... Naked' and make your own comparisons: The original album with its overdubbed strings, choir, between-song banter (John singing 'Danny Boy'... badly!) and the outtakes-posing-as-songs 'Maggie Mae' and 'Dig It'. Or the new version with its straight-up, straight-faced arrangement of the original's songs, complete with differently sung verses and an overall, cleaner sound.  'One After 909' actually suffers a bit from this digital revamp: It ends too abruptly, as if someone ran over to the stereo and turned the volume down as fast as they could.  'Across The Universe' is indeed a revelation, back to it's plucky form, and John's final \\"Jai Guru, deva\\" vocals fade into the distance.  'The Long And Winding Road' is very spare, with an almost demo sound to it, and a welcome absence of harp strings that closed out the original.  'I've Got A Feeling' has a slightly more raw sound, with no gimmicky 'Paul is singing his verse only in this speaker, while John sings in this one'.  'Let It Be' is now made up of different, better takes, and omits the silly \\"And now we'd like to do 'Ark the angels come\\" intro.  The Fly On The Wall bonus disc features bitterness-free band conversation, and bits and pieces of songs from other Beatle/solo albums.  'John's Piano Piece' will eventually become the intro to 'Imagine', and the whole band joins in for George's 'All Things Must Pass'.  This is, first and foremost, a Beatles album for the die-hard fans and the completists.  They'll love it.  They'll welcome it with open arms and ears.  But mostly it's an album to listen to for its sheer curiosity factor.  PS. Check out EMI's guilt-trip message on illegal downloading and copying on the inside of the CD's jewel case!

Track 8 is a great first ballad by the Strokes, and one of my favorites. Julian Casablancas seems to have expanded his writing, and it shows. The riffs, however, are not exactly original. They are still good riffs, but they have the feel of the 70s, yet it still seems original when mixed with synthesizers or distorted vocals. Keep up the good work, Julian and company.

B0000DJZA5|5.0|I have been a fan of the Beatles for over 30 years and this previously was my least favorite Beatles album. Now with all of the Phil Spector added orchestration removed, what is left is a window into the soul of this music... I would classify it as the new \\"White Album\\". The highlights of this reborn material are the stripped down version of The Long And Winding Road with Paul's now more poignant vocals and piano accompaniment. I also greatly enjoyed  Don't Let Me Down, One After 909 and Across The Universe. I actually prefer the \\"Spectorized\\" version of Get Back. The real test though was would my seven year-old son like it? A most enthusiastic yes as I watched him in the rear-view mirror rock out to the various cuts...33 years have passed and the Beatles still reveal that they knew how make ageless music...
0805209999|5.0|In Franz Kafka's novel 'The Trial', Joseph K., an upstanding citizen of a civilized state, is arrested in his home on charges that are never disclosed. His accuser is never disclosed, nor is the law explained. The dehumanizing bureaucracy and arcane, corrupt legal process is, despite the bizarre character of Kafka's novel, both comic and chilling. Among other things, 'The Trial' is a warning to good people everywhere who, through their failure to act against usurpations of authority and abuses of power, are complicit in the illegal or unethical actions of those exercising control over their society. Joseph K. is undone as much by his insistence on maintaining perfect decorum and civility as he is by accepting the notion that he has no right or agency to ignore or overcome the ridiculous and immoral process through which he is destroyed. Kakfa's expressed fears remain relevant today even for those who, living in a democratic nation, assume that due legal process guarantees justice, the protection of individual privacy, and subsequent civil liberties.<br />Copyright 2003 by Brian D. Sadie, executive director, The Joseph K. Foundation. Used by permission.<br />Also recommended: To Kill A Mockingbird The Unbearable Lightness of Being Catch-22 The Name of the Rose

0671027344|2.0|Reading other reviews has reinforced my belief that this is the perfect book for teenageers who wouldn't otherwise read anything. Everyone else should steer clear. Written in a dumbed-down journal style filled with random words in quotation marks (presumably stylistically, but really annoying), Chbolsky tells the story of a disturbed but intelligent uncool kid who meets Alternative Friends and finds his Coolness Within.<br />Like Charlie, the protagonist, I was 15 in 1991, so I thought I could relate to the world this book is set in. I was wrong. This book sets up a fictionalized version of the 90s that Chbolsky (I would imagine around 25 in 1992) would like to think existed, but didn't. Overall, this book was pretentious and so breezy it could float away. I could tell it was trying to be deep and significant, but totally missed its mark. Other writers have dealt with misfits in so many better, non-superficial ways. Salinger this is not (although I have a feeling it would like to be). When I reached the end, I discovered that this book was published by MTV. 'Nuff said.<br />If you are (or know someone who is) a 14-year-old who doesn't fit in, or are someone who NEVER READS ANYTHING but needs a book for your Friendster profile, this is the book for you. Everyone else, stay away.

Several sweet, bittersweet, and downright painful relationships unfold during the movie. In one way or another, one story ends up being linked to another which is linked to another...<BR>A synopsis of the stories...<BR>Hugh Grant is the new, dashing British Prime Minister who has fallen in love with his tea lady...the tea lady lives next door to a lusty young minx who is throwing herself at  her boss Alan Rickman...Rickman is intrigued but perplexed as he has been married for years to Emma Thompson (Hugh Grant's sister in the movie)...Thompson meanwhile is comforting her best friend, Liam Nesson, who has recently been widowed...Neeson is helping his 10-year old stepson deal with a crush...and so on. I think that in reality we all are. <BR>   This is a film to be treasured for the ages. And, to be incomprehended for an equal amount of time. Peace...
B000002KON|5.0|This, I have no doubt, is the most underappreciated album in rock n' roll history. Not only is it, without any doubt, the Kinks' best, it should be on every list of top British albums, right up there with Sgt. Pepper, Tommy, Sticky Fingers and Dark Side of the Moon. The Kinks are best known as one of the leading bands of the British Invasion of the mid-60s, and for hits like You Really Got Me and Waterloo Sunset, but on this, their finest work, Ray Davies and the boys make no attempt to invade. They stay right where they are, and discuss the bleak shape of like in the UK in the late 60s. That may explain why it didn't do as well outside the UK as albums by the Who or the Stones; Arthur is a much smaller affair, more local in the issues it tackles. Musically and thematically, though, it's a genuine work of genius, and while the album refers to a very small frame in time and place, it's still relevant, and it still lingers.<br />As a rock opera, Arthur isn't as coherent as others from the period like Tommy or Jesus Christ Superstar, but it still holds its own at the very least as a concept album. If you still want a plot, the story of Arthur, as written by Ray Davies and Julian Mitchell, can be found in the CD booklet, and it may give some frame within which all the songs can fit, but it's not necessary. The story is of Arthur Morgan, average working class citizen, and his family; it takes place on the day his son, Derek, moves with his family to Australia. The story follows Arthur's and Derek's relationship, but most of the songs are flashbacks to Arthur's life. In reality, Arthur's story is the story of Britain, and the album is perfect satire. It manages to be hilarious and at the same time touching and thought-provoking, and the lyrics are sharp and venomous. Thus, songs like `Shangri-La' and `She Bought A Hat Like Princess Marina' are powerful statements about the working class in England, `Some Mother's Son' - a song about the death of Arthur's eldest son, Eddie, in the Korean war - is a touching song that could be about any soldier who was killed in any war anywhere, and `Nothing To Say', a song sung by Derek about his relationship with his father, is actually a summing of the feeling in the UK at the time. Like Chaplin, Benini and Monty Python, Mr. Davies also discovered that the best way to make a point is by making people smile, and the light-hearted sound and catchy melodies of this album are what make it classic satire just like `The Great Dictator' and `Life Of Brian'.<br />Aside from that, many of the songs on Arthur stand fully by themselves as terrific rock songs. The bandmates' instrumental prowess, while they're still no Who, is at its best - Dave Davies supplies some of his finest guitar work for Arthur. Also, while the production is light and small and the melodies are simple - which gives the album a lot of strength, special attention should be given to the arrangements, which are brilliant and perfect. The inclusion of a horn section on some of the songs adds a lot, and the horn arrangements are terrific. The best horns can be found on the album's greatest track, `Shangri-La', which remains one of the finest songs of all time. The different segments all combine wonderfully, from the acoustic opening to the hard, horn driven middle part, to the slow and powerful ending. The lyrics, too, as well as Ray's vocal performance, are splendid. The album has many other wonderful moments: `She Bought A Hat Like Princess Marina', which sounds almost like a Monty Python skit, is funny and strong satire at its finest, with brilliant lyrics. `Mr. Churchill Says' is another brilliant piece of political commentary, and the bit in the middle where the sirens come in is absolutely chilling.<br />`Brainwashed' is another strong social-political number, which is attributed to Eddie's son (Arthur's grandson), Ronnie - that excuses itself, because by attributing the songs to a character in the story the Kinks don't commit to oneopinion or line of thinking, but when considered by itself `Brainwashed' is an incredibly strong, venomous piece:<br />The aristocrats and bureaucrats <BR>Are dirty rats for making you what you are <BR>They're up there and you re down here <BR>You're on the ground and they're up with the stars <BR>All your life they've kicked you around and pushed you around<BR>Till you can't take any more<BR>To them you're just a speck of dirt<BR>But you don't want to get up off the floor <br />`Yes Sir No Sir' and `Some Mother's Son' both discuss military life and the part the military plays in everyday life - `Yes Sir No Sir' is a funny and strong satire (with great guitar work), while `Some Mother's Son' is a tender and touching ballad, but both songs complete each other. And once again, `Nothing To Say' is a lovely rock song which sums up the feelings of the album better than any other song. Even the lesser songs - `Victoria', `Australia', `Young And Innocent Days', `Drivin'' and `Arthur' - are well worthy of much praise, and they all fit neatly and perfectly into the bigger picture. That is the sign of a great album, and that's why I compared Arthur with Tommy and Sgt. Pepper, both of whom also share this quality.<br />The Kinks will never be as widely recognized as their peers the Stones and the Who, because they were never as global, but their heritage will remain. On Arthur the Davies brothers brought their three chord songs, strictly pentatonic guitar and simplistic rock n' roll drums to new levels or artistry, not to mention the lyrics; and Arthur rocks like few other mainstream rock of the time. Add it to your collection - you won't regret it.
B00009W0U4|3.0|By now, &quot;Irreversible&quot; is building a massive reputation for being a ultraviolent film and on this feature alone it's becoming one of the most known indie films of the year.<BR>    The question whether it deserves this reputation in this respect should be answered with a thunderous yes. &quot;Irreversible&quot; is a film filmed backwards. It begins with a disturbing murder in an SÂ§M club, continues with the frantic search by a small mob for the person who gets killed and proceeds with probably the most unsubtle rape scene ever recorded on celluloid.<BR>   But this french film actually has more things going for it. The camera work (far from the &quot;dramamine&quot; metaphors that others see) is brilliant. Photography and camera work go hand-in-hand as they build a dark doomy environ where the whole story keeps settling in geometrically. The cast is exceptionally picked as the actors come across perfectly as the everyday characters involved in a sudden nightmare.<br />   I personally dont understand why the graphic violence annoys certain people. The violence depicted in this film is but a mere fraction compared to the real, daily violence going on in the real world, and in most cases not far (if not right in) from our own neighborhoods. The bombardment -for example- of civilians is not &quot;annoying&quot; because the media try hard to hide it from the public but this film is? Lets be serious.<BR>   Back to the film, i loved the way the landscape brightens as the film progresses to its end (which is of course the beginning) and as the colors open up as from a dommy eternal sunset to a colorful dawn, obviously the directors intent to emphasize contrast.<br />    The only minus in my opinion, was that the &quot;end&quot; was basically an anticlimax and for this it loses in my view a couple of stars. On one hand this is understandable keeping in mind that the rest of the film is super intimidating, but nevertheless, a different idea should've been used to climax the pivot of the story. It wasnt easy but the fact that it was predictable spoils an otherwise very good film.<BR>    A disturbingly unsubtle addition to dark cinema.

0764113496|5.0|Unlike Turkish or Japanese (in which the irregular verbs can be counted on the fingers of one hand, at least in the case of Japanese), Russian, like Latin, Spanish, German, and many other languages, has lots of both regular and irregular verbs. Spanish, which I know better than Russian, has 22 commonly used verbs that are irregular in the present indicative tense, and the same 18 are also irregular in the present subjunctive. But 12 of those have the same pattern in the present indicative, so once you get this idea, the situation is not as bad as it at first seems. There are similar patterns in Russian, and it helps to have them laid out for you and explained, which this book does. As someone pointed out, the hundreds of pages of regularly conjugated verbs really aren't needed once you get the pattern for the regular ones, and this book could have been reduced to a few pages that way, but for beginners it's still useful to have that.<br />Considering that language learners now have the choice of getting handheld language translation computers like the well-known models from Franklin, which aren't that much more than this book, and which will give you the definitions of 60,000 words, along with other notes on the grammar, games, word completion, and other features, it's interesting to see that these books are still surviving so well.<br />One useful feature is the section where the colloquial uses of various verbs are explained, which is useful too, and the Spanish version of this book has the same feature. This section focuses on commonly used verbal phrases that are not unlike the ones in use in English that cause so many problems for foreign speakers. These are phrases like &quot;run away from, or come up on,&quot; in English. But since English has done away with case markers and now mostly relies on word order, there are many more thousands of them in English than in Russian or Spanish. NTC's recent dictionary of English verbal phrases and phrasal verbs listed 12,000.<br />But getting back to this book, this is still an excellent reference for the beginner to intermediate speaker and I can recommend it for that.2,000. <br />But getting back to this book, this is still an excellent reference for the beginner to intermediate speaker and I can recommend it for that.

B00005N6KG|5.0|When you find yourself searching, in need a pair of headphones, you should ask yourself what you want from your music. Do you want a sound that seems to cover you ear, muffling the noise and perhaps minimizing exposure, or do you want purity of sound that closeness of proximity can bring? Do you want a design that might be right and that might not, with those newer designs that hook behind the ears or those sectional ones that sometimes pinch, or do you want a more basic model that has been time tested? While you might not think of it, how you answer that question makes all the difference in the world. And if you're picky and want something that has met the measure of thousands of hours of this reviewer's personal testing, then this model works.<br />Before the advent of volume control on headphones, this was only the way to go and is still the type I fall back on when I can't find that type. That's because they have a durable plastic structure, an adjustable fit that is pretty hard to wear out, and speakers that seem to take a sonic beating before giving out. Its actually amazing when you note the beating they can take, with so many other products falling by the consumer wayside. Also, they fit firmly in the ear, seating themselves properly, and the plug connecting the headphones to the player rarely wear rout. Besides that, they have one other thing going for them. They are formed well, especially around the speakers.<br />While many may not see this as a necessity, I've actually experimented with all types of headphones and I've found something that can happen when straying away from Sony. If you're lucky you'll get something that is wired decently, sometimes popping and giving the equal to a shock in the ear and sometimes not, and at worst you'll have a form with a jagged surface. While that might not be bad with something that fits over the ear, something inserted directly into the ear is dangerous when not formed properly. And that's why I swear by these because I've never, in well over 50 pairs of this model alone, had it happen.<br />If you look at these and you think they are to basic and that the price says something on lower quality, you'd be wrong in many a right. They are perhaps plain in design, not getting fancy in color or the way they fit, but they deliver sounds in only a way that Sony seems to understand. They also last, allowing you to get your maximum use out of the product. Personally, I find that to be the best way to secure loyalty as a customer and something Sony seems to understand. And they've been doing that for me for well over a decade.ause I've never, in well over 50 pairs of this model alone, had it happen.<br />If you look at these and you think they are to basic and that the price says something on lower quality, you'd be wrong in many a right. B00005JKHP|2.0|Footnote: Official Review: ** 1/2 (two star and a half star rating)<br />In 1979, Robert Wise's (West Side Story, The Sound of Music, The Haunting) highly budgeted, enormously special effects laden, immensely epic, and dramatically devoid of feeling Star Trek: The Motion Picture hit theaters around the world introducing new fans to the new continuing chronicles of Admiral James T. Kirk (William Shatner), stoic Science Officer half human/half Vulcanian Spock (Leonard Nimoy), and sardonically comedic Doctor Leonard &quot;Bones&quot; Mc Coy (DeForest Kelley). In the vast horizon of space, there appears to be an immensely lethal gigantic space being intelligence (that goes by the name of V'Ger) that after already easily annihilating several Kilingon Birds of Prey and a Federation Deep Space Station facility is on a direct collision course with the planet Earth. So of course the United Federation of Planets allows recently promoted Admiral Kirk to helm the U.S.S. Enterprise on an extremely vital emergency mission to investigate the mystery alien's intentions. Unfortunately for all but the most blindly devoted of the Trekkie fan base, the film lacked the one crucial engineering ingredient that made the original series glisten amongst all the other one-dimensionally conventional entertainments of the time, character, dimensionality, and humanity.<br />Though we do see momentary glimpses of the Shatner/Nimoy/Kelly character dynamic that propelled the original series ascendance into the syndication stratosphere, Star Trek: The Motion Picture creatively concentrates on a mightily bland ambiguous creature that never really fulfills on it's promise of threat to the audience (only cerebrally never emotionally), adheres too stridently to an old Hollywood pacing structure (form the 50's and 60's) that clashes as badly to Star Trek as platform shoes stand out at a Moshe pit, focuses on a very uninteresting romance between the first officer and a bald female navigator (both before and after one of them becomes an android), and horrendously confuses telling a intensely jargon-filled space odyssey with that of concocting a compellingly motion picture. Though the grave somber literate bent of the film is not lost upon this reviewer, the emblematic spice of argumentative dissension between friends, the palpable and utterly real danger of space travel, spontaneous comedic innuendo that punctuated pompousness away from the drama, and the very fabric of camaraderie that richly effortlessly soared in the series is about as subdued and unappreciatively undeveloped as comedy was previously in any old Dragnet episode. Wise only in a very theatrical or heavily staged manner even remotely alludes to the venerable dependably timeless elements that made Star Trek always and exclusively Star Trek. His \\"lively\\" touches of character spontaneity, enthusiastic mood, and jovial levity would have been made traumatically more believable if only they had been frantically re-imaged in a wax museum showcase instead. <br />One dedicated fan may point out the fact that in the initial scenes of Star Trek: The Motion Picture, Spock was undergoing a Vulcanian emotional purging ceremony entitled Kolinahr. Given his increasing resolute attempts to purge his own emotions as a character, these strides may have had a &quot;direct&quot; (maybe even commendable consistency of character to some) effect on the profuse mundane character uneventfulness that is being described. This certainly is attributed in the film but where oh where is that legendary DeForest Kelley or James Doohan wit when we ravenously agonize over their absence of them most?  Sure there are minor colorful moments prudishly infrequently dispensed throughout the film from point to point. Yet this &quot;levity&quot; is never relentlessly exceptional enough to lug 136 minutes around with it without considerable waisline coverage issues apparent form head to foot.<br />All in all, despite an all-star cast, mind bogglingly excellent special effects, and a superbly noteworthy soundtrack by Jerry Goldsmith (that track was later re-used in the vastly popular Star Trek: The Next Generation), Star Trek: The Motion Picture fails to go where almost all of it's sequels later went on to do, make an entertaining picture. It certainly is worth mention and inclusion to one's cinema-going experiences solely for that legendarily diabolically seductive musical score, watching the U.S.S. Enterprise (accompanied by Goldsmith's eternal score) leaving the Federation Space dock for the first time, viewing the Enterprise warping away into the distance at the film's conclusion, witnessing that infamously beloved Leonard Nimoy eyebrow twinge, and its paternal role as the first feature-length film in the Star Trek film franchise. However don't these scattered moments appear more like anemic scrapes than an entire fluid film ahcievement to you? Other than those inclusions, this is about as barren as the Starship U.S.S. Reliant at the conclusion of Nicholas Meyer's Star Trek 2: The Wrath of Khan in terms of shear excitement that is. Yet in its favor, its mere trespasses were only excessively bland in comparison with the quality atomic bomb that that was William Shatner's vindictively baleful masterpiece of calamites, Star Trek 5: The Final Frontier. Now that was a cinematic Watergate for the ages.<br />As for the Star Trek: the Motion Picture Director's Cut DVD Special Edition, it's includes a marvelously remastered anamorphic widescreen presentation, a Robert Wise commentary track, 3 documentaries, 11 deleted scenes, and more impressive Star Trek options to shake a replicated steak at. <br />Highly recommended for any Trekkie with a thirst for antiquity, but for all other indifferent non-fans stay as far away from this as you would from the Influencian Flu or Barclay's Proto-morphosis Syndrome. You've been warned<br />P.S. Scotty thin? Naw...<br />Followed by Nicholas Meyer's Star Trek 2: The Wrath of Khan.

B0000DJZA5|3.0|I love The Beatles but I have to admit that this CD does not add a single thing to their legacy. The Let It Be album was probably the weakest album the group recorded as evidenced by the fact that they got back together at the end of the year and recorded a \\"proper\\" album, Abbey Road. There are some good songs amidst this bunch, but between the bickering, close pressured setting, Yoko's presence and John's heroin addiction, the Let It Be / Get Back project was doomed for failure. The concert on the rooftop was probably the most enjoyable thing that came from the entire experiment. For a really good (though outdated) resource on the Get Back sessions then check out the Doug Sulpy Get Back Disaster book. I have had the fortunate experience to wade through hours upon hours of Get Back material and believe me; you can only do so much with the available material. This is not a masterpiece by any means.<br />As for the sound of the album, I believe the sound is very good and the vocals are so clear and crisp it sounds like they are standing next to you when they are singing. Let It Be...Naked is only 35 minutes long. Along with the 1 track 21-minute \\"fly on the wall\\" bonus disk it totals only 54 minutes. Why is this set 2 CD's? It seems like an awful waste to me. If you have the original then this is not essential.<br />Is it me or does Paul get greedier and cheesier every year? I am pretty sure John would have liked to fix up some of his songs that he felt were never properly recorded like Strawberry Fields Forever and Across The Universe. B0000DJZA5|5.0|This CD is unmistakeable evidence of the Beatles magic.  From the first note of 'Get Back' you can hear that this new version has been produced and mixed with great skill and care.  The sound quality is captivating: the voices and instruments are tightly mixed to give you an arresting, immediate experience of the men at work.  If you want to know what is the magic of the Beatles -- the songs or the singers?  the voices or the instruments? -- the production team for this reissue gives you the answer: Yes!  The old journalistic criticisms of this album no longer apply: this is not rehearsal music and it's not the sound of a band past their prime.  Remember, they had not yet started on Abbey Road when these tunes were recorded.  I agree with other reviewers that it's no longer adequate to just give us the original tracks (minus two!).  The Fly On The Wall disc is a poor substitute for the additional songs we expect on a reissue.  But we can't complain about what we've got.  With Phil Spector's horribly misjudged over-production removed and the songs all there for the enjoyment, you can savor every track for its authentic, satisfying Beatles feel.  For fans, there are just too many happy musical moments to list here.  For someone less familiar with the band or this album, you aren't going to be disappointed.   You might have thought of it as Paul's album, as he is the soloist on two of the better known tracks 'The Long and Winding Road' and 'Let It Be'.  But that's not so.  One of the successes of this production is to show us just how good John's rock n roll voice is.  But of course, this is not a recording of distinct individuals but a band as cohesive as you'll hear anywhere.  I particularly liked 'I've Got A Feeling' and 'One After 909' as examples of John and Paul's mastery of their musical art.  After all this rapture I have to mention the one big disappointment: Track 4, 'The Long and Winding Road'.  For me, this track was always the centrepiece of the album, andit was the one I most looked forward to hearing in its original form.  But what we get is below standard.  The vocal is average, and there's a particularly awful keyboard interlude, sounding less like a keyboard than a children's toy.  We've already been given a 'naked' version of this track -- on Anthology 3 -- and I wanted to hear something better; but this isn't it.  Dig out your Anthology 3 set and listen to what this track should have been (Disc 2, Track 8).

These may be from those sessions and it would make sense why they weren't featured on that album...they're just not very good. <br />Skip this and try 'Tug Of War', 'Flowers In The Dirt' and 'Flaming Pie' instead. B0000CEB4V|5.0|In his own way, even from beyond the material world, George Harrison once again resets the standards for excellenec in music and film. As was the case with the CONCERT FOR BANGLA DESH, THE CONCERT FOR GEORGE is a work born of tremendous compassion, and if you were to distill George Harrison to one word and say it into the air, you would rightly intone: Compassion.<BR>So, from the opening &quot;Sarve Shaam&quot; with its intenseley deep ochre and crimson overtones through Olivia's lighting the lamp for her husband and Eric Clapton's and then Ravi Shankar's beautifully affecting remarks, you know this is a work of very deep love. And it is shot gorgeously, as it should from the man who produced TIME BANDITS and LIFE OF BRIAN. The classical Indian pieces that open the movie are deeply spiritual pieces that set the context for a man whose life dealt with his devotion to his family, his faith, his craft, his friends. Clapton is positively eloquent as he searches for a way to maintain his composure and find the right words for a friend who espoused a less is more ethic in his work to great effect. Shankar speaks with such profound love that it fills your heart. His daughter Anoushka attends respectfully to her father and then plays her heart out. It is glorious!<BR>Less things get too sentimental, Eric Idle and chums arrive for a bawdy version of both &quot;Sit On My Face&quot; and Michael Palin's hilarious intro to &quot;The Lumberjack Song.&quot;<BR>How else would you segue from Indian ragas to Beatle tunes?<BR>When Dhani Harrison and Jeff Lynne lead the houseband back on, the concert is an incredible celebration of some of Harrison's best compositions. Every guest delivers the goods, but certainly the emotional highpoint is Ringo's &quot;Photograph&quot; and Paul's &quot;Something.&quot; Clapton is incredible throughout. Tom Petty essya the Wilbury's period and Billy Preston breathes revival fervour into &quot;My Sweet Lord.&quot; Dhani is terrific throughout and lendsan eerie presence playing behind Clapton, every bit the countenance of his father beaming through him.<BR>This film is a triumph on so many levels that it is unlikely that rock will ever elevate itself to this level again anytime in the foreseeable future. When it all resolves into Joe Brown's take on &quot;I'll See You In My Dreams,&quot; you realize what a profound proverb the Chinese admonition is: &quot;Money means nothing. To be loved and remembered is everything.&quot;<BR>Farewell, George, we'll see you in our dreams.

This statement speaks with an incredible honesty to the sound of the record itself.  With very good reason, when they came out with &quot;Is This It?&quot; the Strokes were critically acclaimed, perhaps more than anyone else as, as the best new rock group to come about in a long time.  In order to appease their critacal aclaim, as well as their rabid fan base, the Strokes had to deliver a second album which followed largely in the footsteps of its predecessor; A solid collection of simple rock songs, following a similar formula to &quot;Is This It.&quot;  This is exactly what the guys did with &quot;Room On Fire.&quot;<br />On the weak points: The album sounds far less original and captivating as the first.  Rather than adding new dimensions to the band &quot;Room on Fire&quot; often ends up sounding like a collection of B-Sides to &quot;Is This It&quot; The song that most sounds like it is breaking across new ground for the band is ironically, the single, 12:51.  The mix tends to at times get a little too &quot;crazy lo-fi.&quot;  Though the &quot;Lo-Fi sound&quot; is a trademark signature of the band, it sounds like the band or producers are trying too hard to get a certain sound. (The beginning, and main riff to &quot;The Way It Is&quot; sounds like a Nu-Metal song which never gets its feet off the ground and into &quot;Hi-Fi&quot;) Their performances on Late Night with Conan O'Brien actually have a much better sounding mix than the record.... and that is coming live from crappy speakers on a 19 inch television. Overall I think the band gets caught up too heavily on trying to sound a certain way on the recording and the tracks get somewhat sterilized, not being able to fufill much of their full potential as solid rock tracks.<br />On the strong points:  This is far from a real dissapointment.  Maybe a little bit of a let down,but it would be hard for any band to follow up an album as strong as &quot;Is This It.&quot;  The overall album is still an excellent peice of work, as well as a fresh breath of air in these dwindling times of mainstream rock.  The Stokes sound like what a real, proper, rock band should sound like.  Not making guitar distortion as a kind of refinement (Hence all the Metal groups with the low mids on their Mesa Boogie Rectifiers)the Strokes keep the sound of Rock and Roll as it should be; Raw, Pure, and Unmolested. They are all about the music, and don't give a damn about image, even if they look cool as hell.  The singer stills stares blankly and borishly out at the crowd, which is almost humourous.  It spits in the face of all else mainstream, from the pop dancers moving in prastic synchrony, to the Nu-Metal bands foolishly jumping around the stage as if they had just crapped their own pants.  The Strokes are a treasure that is here to stay.
B0000DJZA5|2.0|I am proud to say that I am an extreme Beatles fanatic, have attempted to collect every work of theirs available, British, American, Russian, Japanese, etc., including the rarities, bootlegs, outtakes, sessions, and have always loved the rootsy, drunken &quot;Get Back&quot; Sessions the best, with &quot;Commonwealth,&quot; &quot;Suzy's Parlour,&quot; &quot;In the Middle of an Island&quot; and &quot;Take This Hammer,&quot; just to name a few of the boys' beloved underground classics (not to mention all those bluesy jams with Billy Preston).  Sadly for you, you won't hear any of that on this album.  <br />I have been waiting for the real &quot;Get Back&quot; to be released since the early 70's, when I first learned that Phil Spector had allegedly mucked up what was supposed to be a very earthy back-to-basics hippyfied r&amp;b oldies jam, and hoping that I didn't die before I got to hear it.  The famous &quot;Black Album&quot; bootleg and the more recent &quot;Thirty Days&quot; bootleg kept my hopes alive in the intervening decades.  This &quot;Naked&quot; album is not that dream come true; it is a bitter disappointment.  <br />The song &quot;Get back&quot; is mutilated.  Where is the &quot;hope we passed the audition&quot; bit, the &quot;high heeled sneakers and low neck sweater&quot; bit, the reprise?  What a headache any true fan is sure to get hearing Get Back jar right into &quot;Dig a Pony&quot; without time to take a breath.  That part alone causes one to suspect that the Beatles did not listen to this record carefully before approving its release.    Why did they not include the whole &quot;Dig It&quot; (of which some of the cut out portions were better than what was released)?  Poor old Maggie Mae; they really have taken her away; and she'll never walk our night streets anymore.  Why did they not include &quot;Maggie Mae,&quot; with the charming little &quot;Fancy Me Chances&quot; ditty at the end?  <br />Winston O'Boogie is right; what the world needs now ismore Beatles music, not less!  I suppose one could jerry rig a proper &quot;Get Back&quot; album by burning together bits from Anthology 3, the bootlegs, the original album, this album and the &quot;Let It Be&quot; movie (if only it were easy to get the &quot;Let It Be&quot; movie on DVD anywhere outside the former Soviet bloc), but that would be illegal.  Even an audio track of the movie itself would be much better than this new album.  At least there you'll find a little version of &quot;You've really got a hold on me&quot; that will put a smile on your face.  <br />If anyone has the chance to listen to the actual &quot;Get Back&quot; sessions, copies of which are still floating around out there, or Vigotone's &quot;Thirty Days,&quot; or the &quot;Glynn Johns Mixes&quot; of the &quot;Get Back&quot; album, or Yellow Dog's &quot;Get Back and 22 Other Songs&quot;, I would recommend that they do so.  If you can tolerate a few botched notes or words here or there, you're in for a treat.  The &quot;Get Back&quot; sessions contain many diamonds in the rough, none of which made it onto the &quot;Naked&quot; disc.  <br />The &quot;Naked&quot; record is a ripoff, which I give two stars only because I also cannot give the Beatles the lowest score on anything, even if I am disappointed that they would allow their name to be attached to such a rip off.  <br />Those who are only infants today may be able to hope that one day, in their elder years (assuming that advances in medicine extend the average life expectancy by a few decades and that Congress doesn't squeeze through another sweetheart copyright extension for the industry at the expense of the public), they'll be able to listen to the real thing in the public domain without fear of persecution by EMI and the RIAA.  Until then, fans are still at the mercy of the monopolists, and will have to settle for second rate releases like this one. It is worse than Phil Spector's version (something I would have had trouble imaginingbefore today).<br />Those who say that the &quot;Let It Be&quot; album (at least an idealized version of the same) is not excellent do not have any appreciation for rock &amp; roll music.  It should have been one of the best albums in rock history, especially with &quot;Dig a Pony&quot;, &quot;I've Got a Feeling&quot; and &quot;One After 909,&quot; three gritty masterpieces that earn the fab four a place, with the Rolling Stones, Led Zeppelin and the Allman Brothers, up in the Honky Tonk Valhalla.  However, this &quot;Naked&quot; version does not bring us any closer to the true eidos (Platonic form) of the new-phase Beatle album promised all those years ago.  Alas, we true &quot;Get Back&quot; fans must continue to lament, in the words of the Walrus, &quot;don't keep me waitin' . . .&quot;<br />Sorry, Paul and Ringo, I didn't want to have to feel this way about one of your records; you just got my hopes up and let them down.  <br />Fans, Beware!!!  The Emperor has no clothes!!!!!!!
B000002NZO|5.0|Following a major debut slump album that lacked good production, good publicity and even a good name (called &quot;From Genesis to Revelation&quot; it got stored alongside religious albums in many record stores), in 1970 Genesis recorded what would be known as the true beginning of their prog rock sound.<br />While the lineup differed slightly from the 'classic' Genesis we got used to between 1971 and 1975 (Phil Collins still wasn't a part of the band, and neither was Steve Hackett, whose place was occupied by the brilliant guitarrist Anthony Phillips), the core of the band's seminal sound was already present, with Tony Banks' keys complementing the 'pastoral' (for lack of a better term) guitars of Mike Rutherford and Phillips in a very edgy way, and with Peter Gabriel singing and hovering with his flute over all the instruments like a maestro.<br />Songs to pick? Quite a challenge, indeed. The biggest song to come out of this album (in more than one sense) was clearly &quot;The Knife&quot;, a song in a Bolero (by Ravel) rhythm, that could have easily been picked to coin what the term progressive rock sounded like: strong, lyrical and rhythmical filled with passion to the bones, with keys and guitars giving the song an almost orchestral-like life. But the track that gave the cover its reason for being (flip the cover, so that you can see what I mean) is far from being the only valuable song in the album: &quot;White Mountain&quot; and &quot;Visions of Angels&quot; were a regular part of the band's live repertoire before the time came for more elaborate works, such as Foxtrot's &quot;Supper's Ready&quot; or the concept work &quot;The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway&quot;. &quot;Stagnation&quot; and &quot;Dusk&quot; are also equally bound to make you rejoice at the quality of the early work of a band of young brilliant musicians in their early twenties, in the beginning of a musical movement whose bulk would take the bigger part of the early seventies.<br />After listening to the album for the first time, if it's (hopefully) your first time listening to &quot;old&quot; Genesis, the good news is that there's plenty more that can be found where this majestic work of art comes from, to satisfy even the most curious of musical souls. If you go chronologically through the band's work, you are bound to encounter extremely enriching musical works up to 1977's 'And Then There Were Three' (the album following the departure of guitarrist Steve Hackett). Past that point, you gotta watch your step, because you're bound to find all sorts of things, ranging from brilliant (some of the tracks in 'Duke' are, for example, as well as most of 'We Can't Dance', the last album with Phil Collins) to sheer mediocre (most of the albums posthumous work are worth about 1 star).g to the album for the first time, if it's (hopefully) your first time listening to &quot;old&quot; Genesis, the good news is that there's plenty more that can be found where this majestic work of art comes from, to satisfy even the most curious of musical souls. If you go chronologically through the band's work, you are bound to encounter extremely enriching musical works up to 1977's 'And Then There Were Three' (the album following the departure of guitarrist Steve Hackett). Past that point, you gotta watch your step, because you're bound to find all sorts of things, ranging from brilliant (some of the tracks in 'Duke' are, for example, as well as most of 'We Can't Dance', the last album with Phil Collins) to sheer mediocre (most of the albums posthumous work are worth about 1 star).

B000000HRP|5.0|Life is not without ironies and this album confirms again one of rock's most interesting ones. As if his work with Genesis were not proof enough of his musical talent, Phil Collins' drumming in this album is bound to leave most drummers and non-drumming music fans speechless, as he glides through the tracks of this album by Brand X, his side project in the late seventies.<br />One could think that something just went terribly wrong with Phil, causing him to throw his musical creativity down a deep hole when the eighties kicked in, and throw himself in the hands of commercial pop and musical recycling for a very long embrace that sadly lasts to this day. In any case, there's plenty of musical testimonies to what his musical genius was for a good decade and so, and his works with Brand X is one of them.<br />Brand X is the brainchild of Phil Collins and Atomic Rooster's guitarist John Goodsall (same band where Emerson Lake and Palmer's Carl Palmer came), and in spite of what you'd be inclined to think, their contributions were not the only brilliant moments of this -by most considered their best- album. 'Unorthodox Behaviour' bridges the gap between jazz fusion and prog rock in a way that is unbelievable, walking a fine line (invisible, some might argue) without tumbling, and maintaining a cohesive and well crafted sound that gives the album a well deserved five stars.

B000002552|5.0|For years (1966-75 to be exact), \\"The Basement Tapes\\" were legendary for being both an alluring rumor, and an often bootlegged item. When it was finally released officially nine years after its birth, it served as an essential historical document of the musical bridge that connected (one) the winding down of Bob Dylan's brilliant folk work as he traded it for rocker status and (two) The Band's uncontainable talent ready to explode.<br />The twenty-four gems that comprise \\"The Basement Tapes\\" are trademark Dylan-Band, painting a unique portrait of rural life in Southern creoles, and intriguing Biblical metaphors. Dylan's wordplay and storytelling are well served on numbers like 'Lo and Behold!', 'Clothes Line Saga,' 'Million Dollar Bash,' and 'Tiny Montgomery,' while patches of rock and melancholia present themselves throughout, such as the depression 'Goin' To Acapulco' and the 60s-rock of 'Odds and Ends.' The Band meanwhile assert themselves as the greatest backing band (their status for the time being) that ever lived, and proved they were destined to become just as important as Bob Dylan, shining on compositions that would become Band favorites like 'Tears Of Rage,' 'Yazoo Street Scandal,' 'Bessie Smith,' and 'This Wheel's On Fire.'<br />This double disc document is given the proper CD treatment, and of course for an album recorded in a basement in Big Pink (The Band's house at that time), the remastered polish has its limits, but the rough recording is part of the charm of \\"The Basement Tapes\\"--no matter the less than perfect recording, the album boasts some of the most wonderful compositions and musicianship of the era.

B000000XCH|5.0|If there weren't so many great CCR albums, it would be easy to call this one their best.  Certainly 'Bayou Country', 'Green River', and even 'Willie and the Poor Boys' can be considered their most outstanding record, given minor variations in taste.  I suppose my personal favorite is 'Bayou Country', due to a 14 year-old's nostalgic connection to 'Born On the Bayou', and (as a Detroiter) a love for their great cover of (native Detroiter) Mitch Ryder's hit, 'Good Golly Miss Molly'.<br />Yet it's hard to argue against 'Cosmo's Factory', as it features so many top hits.  'Who'll Stop the Rain' didn't stop scaling the national charts until it hit number one, and 'Travelin' Band' and 'Lookin' Out My Back Door' both peaked at number two.  Even the 'b-sides', appearing on this album, 'Run Through the Jungle' and 'Up Around the Bend' received significant airtime.<br />And none of those are even close to being the best song on the album!<br />That distinction would lie with one of the greatest covers of all time, Creedence's version of 'I Heard It Through the Grapevine', all 665 seconds of it (good thing there wasn't one more second in there!).  While this California band most often projects a southern-rock veneer, 'I Heard It Through the Grapevine' exudes a rhythm that makes you swear you're in the midst of an Indian war dance.  The sound is nothing less than pure genius.  John Fogerty's vocals are gripping, and his lengthy guitar solo's are intoxicating.  Creedence is a great cover band, so much so that most of their covers easily transcend the original versions.  'Cosmo's Factory' includes three other fine covers, 'Ooby Dooby', 'Before You Accuse Me', and 'My Baby Left Me'.  But Marvin Gaye may as well have signed over his 'Grapevine' rights to John Fogerty and CCR... it's that good.<br />Add to these highlights the appropriate closer, 'Long As I Can See the Light' (\\"Put a candle in the window...\\"), and the opener, a seven minute rambling rocker called 'Ramble Tamble', and you have one of the finest albums of the early 1970's.

B000000OU0|2.0|In 1993 or so, I went to see Don Henley in concert and he spoke of new songs he was writing for an Eagles album.  This, of course, got me really excited - I hadn't really discovered the Eagles 'til I was in High School (junior year or so - late 1985/early 1986).  I loved all their studio albums (1972 - 1980) and their live album from 1980 and this announcement from Don Henley got me craving new Eagles music.<br />Maybe it was because my anticipation was so high that this live album, &quot;Hell Freezes Over&quot;, is so disappointing to me.  Yes, indeed, there were four new songs, but to me, they are pretty lackluster efforts compared with almost anything one finds on the Eagles' studio albums from the 1970s...&quot;Get Over It&quot; is an upbeat song, but it is, to this listener at least, pretty dull. Schmit penned (I think...)  &quot;Love Will Keep Us Alive&quot;, which is quite pretty, but which is also not particularly exciting...<br />As for the live songs, the only song here that really stands out is the terrific acoustic version of &quot;Hotel California&quot;...The beautiful Spanish guitar picking and the lovely harmonies of the song make this album almost worth owning...The rest of the set is somewhat subdued in tone - the only one that rocks out is &quot;Life In The Fast Lane&quot;, and this version is really not much different than their studio version or the one you hear in their 1980 live album...&quot;Take It Easy&quot; is one of my favorite songs of all time and it was nice to hear them singing this one again, but once more, it was not very different from the original...and that's the way it seemed with most of the Eagles songs here (Don Henley's &quot;New York Minute&quot; is also done here...) - in other words, they seem rather superfluous when taken in context with their studio and previous live output.<br />Oh people, I'm sorry to have to give this such a lousy review...I wanted so much tolike this album - I rushed right out to get it, but when all was said and done, it was a real disappointment...I suppose I would recommend this only to the Eagles completist (of which I am one) and also possibly to those interested in the great &quot;Hotel California&quot; performance found here...Note that these are good songs and they are well played,  but the songs chosen are not really among my favorite Eagles hits and the new songs just don't cut it...I give this album 2.25 stars and I'll round down to 2...SADLY, NOT RECOMMENDED...

I like Brooklyn's song, a fresh female vocalist.<br />I bought the deluxe version thinking that there would be videos and interviews, possibly a DVD - but it turned out to be only a download of &quot;The Eminem Desksite&quot; which delivers videos and interviews from the internet, maybe twice a month - but it's FREE to download from [...] and I already had it, so I was rather disappointed!<br />As to the soundtrack itself, I just want to say that, in contrast to most reviewers, I LIKE &quot;The Time of My Life&quot;.  It took a while to get used to it, but since this isn't a RAP ALBUM, but is music connected to a film, I think the song fits as part of the story, when you listen to the lyrics.  I also like &quot;Wasting My Time&quot; by Taryn Manning, who played Jimmy's ex-girlfriend Janine in the movie.  She has a good voice, and her song also makes the soundtrack feel like it's telling a story.  But of course the highlights are the 5 raps in which Eminem appears.
B0000DJZA5|4.0|Let It Be... Naked came with a great deal of anticipation. We've all grown up with the original Spectorized version and, prior to Naked's release, many expected a radically different cd. Well, it's halfway there. The Abbey Road folks did do an incredible job in improving the overall sound of the recording. Let it Be and The Long And Winding Road almost sound like entirely different recordings and, I think in the case of TLAWR, possibly an alternate take. For me the standout track in terms of improvement is Across The Universe. All of the instrumentation literally leaps to the forefront while some, such as George's sitar, are apparent, at least for me, for the first time. The remaining tracks are solid but without such a radically different sound. The accompanying Fly On The Wall disc is really for completist fans only. Snippets of conversation and a few early run throughs of songs barely held my interest and probably won't be played again. The primary disc while a great improvement, won't place it above some of the more superior Beatles releases such as Sgt. Pepper, The White Album or Abbey Road.
B00000DCH9|5.0|Back in the summer of 1979, before I knew anything of pop music aside from The Beatles and Simon & Garfunkel, I went to a sleepaway camp where someone in my bunk had this great album.  I didn't know who it was, but I loved these great songs - Piano Man, the song about Billy the Kid.  By 1985, I was getting heavily into music...and of course, being from Long Island, Billy Joel was required listening.  In my effort to find music by this guy that my friends were listening to (and who I knew from the radio from songs like \\"Pressure\\", \\"Allentown\\" and \\"Tell Her About It\\"), I went sifting through my dad's record collection.  I found several there...Trying to go in chronological order, the earliest one I found was \\"Piano Man\\".   When I saw the track listing, I realized that this was that great album that we used to listen to in summer camp.<br />It wasn't long before I became intimately familiar with all the songs on this album.  Nowadays, I don't listen much to Billy Joel (probably because I listened to so much of him during High School), but looking at \\"Piano Man\\" in the context of his other work as well as my exposure to much more and different and varied music over the years, I still feel that this is a really good album from someone who would emerge as one of the premier songwriters of the '70s and '80s.<br />Highlights of this album include the poignant, expressive title track which paints a vivid picture of Billy Joel's experience as a lounge pianist (I believe in L.A.).  He paints great characters in this song which, in itself would make the song really good - of course, then there's the great music of the song.  \\"Captain Jack\\" was another great hit off of this album - an ode to the hopelessness of suburban teenagerdom...Other great songs found here include the rollicking western style \\"The Ballad of Billy The Kid\\", the pretty \\"Your My Home\\" (which my friends used as their wedding first dance song), and two very catchy, lesser-known songs \\"Worse Comes To Worst\\" and\\"Ain't No Crime\\".  Also, \\"Stop In Nevada\\" is a very pretty song which, for me, for reasons other than the just the song title, evokes images of the expanses of the American West...Same thing with \\"Billy The Kid\\", except with that song, the song really does have a western flavor.<br />To sum up, there are two songs here which, as individual songs (\\"Ballad of Billy The  Kid\\" and the title track)are masterpieces when standing alone.  The rest of the songs here range from good to very good.  While not a masterpiece as a whole, it is a very good album - I would give it 4 1/2 stars (to get above this, really every song has to be classic material) and round up to 5 stars...HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

B00004Y6NU|5.0|This is probably the most adventurous of the Dire Straits CDs, featuring long, complex instrumental solos, especially by leader Mark Knopfler whose guitar playing is a wonder.  \\"Telegraph Road\\", one of Knopfler's best songs, is an epic tale in 14 minutes.  \\"Private Investigations\\" starts slow and boring with semi-spoken lyrics but has a spectacular three-guitar, keyboard, and drum instrumental finale.  The bass lays down a heavy slow rhythm, Knopfler's classic acoustic carries the melody, and the rhythm guitar and piano add powerful dramatic riffs.     I was wowed too by \\"It Never Rains\\" which features Knopfler consciously singing like Dylan but then doing his own thing with a long, rocking finale that features a ringing guitar pitched high enough to make your ears tingle.  \\"Love on Gold\\" was recorded about the time that Mark Knopfler was working with Dylan, so the Dylanesque touch is legit.  Did Dire Straits influence Dylan?                There are only five songs (41 minutes of music) on this CD. The complexities of each song make up for their lack of numbers and the instrumentation is as good as any I've ever heard.  These guys can play their instruments.
B000089CJI|5.0|Music like this doesn't get radio play here in Baltimore.  It's too sophisticated.  It's too intelligent.  It's too unique.  The Postal Service's Give Up ain't no music for the masses.  This is an album of refreshing originality and creativity released during a year filled with stale, redundant music topping the charts.  <br />Because I can't survive on a musical diet consisting of the junk on today's radio, I've turned to the internet as a place to discover of new artists.  Through research on Amazon.com, I discovered this album, listened to the samples of album tracks, and decided to buy it.  Give Up has been such a treat - I have thorougly enjoyed this CD - and I just learned that it ranked #3 on Amazon's Editor's list of best albums of 2003.  I'd have to agree with the editor; this album deserves the honor.  <br />Give Up consists of electronic music programmed with compelling melodies, harmonies, rhythms, and effects.  There's a definitive pop sensibility underneath it all, defining the music as more than a listening curiosity - in fact, these songs sound GOOD; they're infectious, and as a listener you'll find yourself singing along.  <br />Speaking of singing, Ben Gibbard's voice is perfectly suited for this music.  He sings with a stoicism and temperance to complement the near machinistic sounds supporting him.  The lyrics are literate, unpredictable, and imaginative.  Jen Wood's appearance as a female vocalist is also a great addition on the tracks where she performs.  <br />There isn't an expendable tune on this album.  Every song is deftly crafted and contains unexpected twists in composition.  This album is clearly a pleaser for the not-so-casual listener.  If you're looking for something more than the inescapable cookie-cutter music all over today's airwaves, then I'd highly recommend this album to you.

B0000AUHPG|5.0|Personal disclaimer: Once Upon a Time in the West is one of my favorite films.<br />Film Rating: 5 out of 5 stars<BR>DVD Video Quality: 4 (which is very good considering it's a 1968 film)<BR>DVD Audio Quality: 3 (ditto)<BR>DVD Features: 3<BR>Overall: 5 stars (for amazing film and great DVD presentation)<br />If you watch Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill, you might notice how heavily it is influenced by Once Upon a Time in the West (among other films, of course). An ambiguous and flawed hero, very evil yet charismatic villain, the way music is used, minimal plot and dialog (later is very rare for Tarantino), and what appears to be style over substance. But I digress.<br />While Once Upon a Time in the West appears to be largely devoid of plot (especially upon first viewing), and perhaps even a little boring to newcomers given its generous running time, underneath its stylish layer are statements larger than life. To me, it summarizes what America was up to that point, an epitaph of the old west. When Jill's theme swells up again for the last time, I am both sadden and hopeful all at once. The effect is very powerful. Regardless of what has happened up to that point (or how little), we realize that a force larger than five central characters has taken over, signaling the end of one era and the beginning of new America.<br />Once Upon a Time in the West marks the first chapter in director Sergio Leone's 'Once Upon a Time' trilogy, which continues with A Fistful of Dynamite and ends with Once Upon a Time in America. In all three films, he collaborated with composer Ennio Morricone to create something of an epic opera. That is, Morricone wrote all the music before the filming began. And indeed, the film plays like an opera with careful compositions and perfectly synchronized action, sound, dialog, and music. Performances are superb throughout, with amazingly authentic looking costumes and sets (all very dirty and worn out looking), beautiful cinematography, and catchy dialogs (sparsely spoken for more dramatic effect). Note: dialog was dubbed later on, sometimes by a different actor (replacing Italian actor), which accounts for dialog and picture going out of synchronization from time to time.<br />Once Upon a Time in the West is heavily influenced by many other westerns (most prominently Johnny Guitar and Shane) and it shows. But it also attempts to summarize and put an end to once popular film genre (until Dances With Wolves and Unforgiven).<br />Paramount has done an outstanding job with this DVD set. Minor signs of edge enhancement notwithstanding, the film has never looked better. The print looks amazingly clean with great shadow details and beautiful range of color. Restored soundtracks, both original mono and remixed 5.1-channel surround sound very good for a 1968 film. I recommend the 5.1-channel track to better appreciate Morricone's beautiful score, which thankfully leaves the dialog and sound effects anchored to the center channel most of the time (instead of gimmickry repositioned mix).<br />The supplemental materials are few in between, but effectively presented. The audio commentary track does a nice job giving newcomers background information (by Leone biographer Christopher Frayling, directors John Carpenter, John Millius, and Alex Cox, Claudia Cardinale, and few others). 3-part short documentaries feature interviews and footage giving background information about the filmmakers, film's origin, makings of the film, and its aftermath. Still photos (particularly noteworthy for showing how much the locations have changed), documentary short on the railroad revolution, and trailer round up the package.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|I've always been intrigued by the story behind the Let It Be album. We all know it was an effort by the band to \\"Get Back\\" to its roots, yet it also exposed the tension in the band. I saw the documentary when I was a kid, and always wondered why the original album sounded different from the movie. Let It Be...Naked doesn't exactly resolve this, but it is intriguing in that shorn of the Spector treatment, we get a truer sense of the intentions for the album. Yet with this cleaned up version, I still wonder if this is what the originally titled \\"Get Back\\" album was supposed to be, and just how much over-dubbing was done on these tracks. Sonically, it sounds wonderful. And many of the tracks use alternate takes from the original Let it Be record(the title track, Long and Winding Road, Dig a Pony, I've Got A Feeling). Get Back is the opening track (as intended?) and though it is one of the Beatles' best tunes, I miss the coda that is edited to the single version, and even the pithy ending on the orginal album. This version just ends abruptly. But I do like the songs stripped of the Spectorization...they do have a more bar band feel. And that's good, because we tend to forget that the Beatles were a great live act. Now can we get the version that Glyn Johns originally mixed *before* Phil Spector?
B0000C9V3T|4.0|While not the best soundtrack for a Quentin Tarantino film -- both &quot;Reservoir Dogs&quot; and &quot;Pulp Fiction&quot; far outshine this one -- &quot;Kill Bill, Volume 1&quot; shows that, once again, Tarantino is highly gifted when it comes to assembling a soundtrack that plays off his passions, showcases his sense of humor, and stands as an enjoyable companion piece to the film, even enjoyed on its own.<br />The soundtrack, like the film, opens with Nancy Sinatra's &quot;Bang Bang,&quot; a song that if it hadn't been performed by an artist whose biggest successes were four decades ago, one would think had been written specifically for the film, as it perfectly captures the theme and underlying tragic tone. As it is, it's a great example of Tarantino's obsessive love of pop culture trivia and a willingness to cram together eclectic, even lunatic, disparate influences.<br />Likewise, the soundtrack shows off his smart alec sense of humor, including his use of the &quot;Ironside&quot; theme song, used in the picture for the Bride's escape from the hospital when she does not have the use of her legs and is a wheelchair-bound refugee. The inclusion of the &quot;Green Hornet&quot; theme is another joke in the same vein.<br />As always, Tarantino includes sound clips from the movie on this soundtrack. Unfortunately, unlike previous efforts, there are only two such clips on this album, and both of them are mix rather quietly, making it difficult to discern what the characters are saying without turning up the volume to a level that will blow out eardrums (or perhaps even speakers) when the music is resumed.<br />This is also an &quot;enhanced&quot; CD, and includes three trailers. B00005JLTN|3.0|This is in response to the controvercy about the labeling of DVD screen formats, and what they mean. If you want the &quot;complete&quot; image that was filmed, many of the Full Screen DVD's contain more screen image than the &quot;matted&quot; Wide Screen...as is the case of Matrix Reloaded. If you freeze frame the exact frame from both versions of Matrix Reloaded (as I did), you will see there is more image on top and bottom of the same scene in the Full Screen version. This unfortunately, is the case with many of the recent releases as studios just &quot;matt&quot; the Full Screen to get a Wide Screen version. Only when they are photographed in a wide screen format (like Cinemascope, Panavision, etc.), do you get more images on the side edges. The MGM website explains this procedure better....also check the difference on the double format DVD's for yourself....they average about 50/50 which formate shows more image.. so the decision about which format to buy will be easier when the studios find a better way to identify the formats and what is important to the buyer .... now, are you totally confused?<BR>   Oh yeah...thought Matrix Reloaded was &quot;entertaining&quot;, but a big let down with loopholes galore....
B00003CXXJ|5.0|To me, it seems that people are overstating how much tweaking Disney's taking in &quot;Shrek.&quot; Unless I missed something, fairy tales didn't begin with the House That Walt Built, and that's what &quot;Shrek&quot; spends most of its time chipping away at. (Of course, there's also a very funny riff on Disneyland when Shrek arrives to see Lord Farquar, but that's really it for pure Disney-bashing.)<br />Adults who might think that they've seen all the funny fairy tales they can handle should think again: While there's enough fart jokes, talking animals and slapstick to keep the kids entertained, &quot;Shrek&quot; is an adult movie, with low key racy jokes (kids who even notice the &quot;big castle compensating for Lord Farquar's deficiencies&quot; gag will likely assume it's talking about his height, or lack thereof), some very (post-)modern looks at fairy tales (Cinderella's described as being emotionally abused ... well, that sounds about right) and the nerve to say that the princess/Prince Charming fantasy so many fairy tales were built around is garbage.<br />Sure, anyone who's ever seen a major motion picture can guess that it ends up with &quot;They All Lived Happily Ever After,&quot; but any movie that starts off with an ogre using a book of classic fairy tales as toilet paper is going to get there in its own backhanded style. Surprisingly, &quot;Shrek&quot; steers around the pitfalls and never becomes cloying or trite or gives up on its own cockeyed realist view of fairy tales and destructive fantasies (as opposed to the perfectly fine and rather sweet, in their own dim way, fairy tale creatures endangered by the evil pro-rationality and pro-order lord).<br />While it's the writing that really makes &quot;Shrek&quot; work, John Lithgow and Eddie Murphy fling themselves into their roles, making what could have been fairly generic animated characters into memorable performances. Murphy in particular seems freed to do his best work when he's hidden from view as in &quot;Mulan,&quot; and Lithgow, whom many now only know through his goofy &quot;Third Rock from the Sun&quot; role, gets to stretch out his more threatening riffs, as he used to prior to landing on the sitcom.<br />&quot;Shrek&quot; is that rarest of animated movies: One that's genuinely fun for the whole family. See it with or without kids, but see it.<br />All of this is further enhanced by a DVD package that, if not stuffed with extras, has all high quality additions actually worth checking out.<br />Highly recommended for kids from 8-80.as in &quot;Mulan,&quot; and Lithgow, whom many now only know through his goofy &quot;Third Rock from the Sun&quot; role, gets to stretch out his more threatening riffs, as he used to prior to landing on the sitcom.<br />&quot;Shrek&quot; is that rarest of animated movies: One that's genuinely fun for the whole family. B00005JLT5|4.0|I am kind of torn as to what to think about this movie.  While watching it, I was annoyed because I have seen it all before. You really get the feeling that you are there.  That makes this movie a journey worth taking.<br />The movie does have some problems.  The hero is not very engaging.  He is like Candide who experiences one adventure after the other, without making any impact. He drugged and sodomized a thirteen year old girl in the US and then fled to Europe.  Should we be honoring such a person?

What makes this band special is the emotional energy Jack White is able to deliver, and it looks like hes able to drink it deep down from some archetypical level straight to his voice and guitar playing. No excess, no artificialisms, nothing unnecessary disturbs this pure flow.
